channel.title: Screen resolutions
channel.description:
Recently I have been asked to make silly little sites and such to gain small income for some friends. The only problem I have had is with working with different screen resolutions, the resolution I use is 1280x1024 and I have been creating my templates in Photoshop. There are three different sites im having problems with, the first one is here: ******* this site will work perfect in 1024 x 768 and lower perfectly, but if I want to go any higher the text and the image will stay to the left, I could simply change the positioning of these but then they would be wrong in a lower resolution. The other 2 I have problems with are myspace div overlays, ****** and ****** where the comment and friends boxes will move away from the image.
Any help would be much appreciated, thanks ;)
(sorry had to edit out the address because they are not verified, PM me if you want them)

item.title: Screen resolutions
item.dc:creator: @Kimber Kimber
item.description:
@Kimber wrote:

I know no Javascript, your code seems easy to interapt, ill try it thanks

Read full topic

item.title: Screen resolutions
item.dc:creator: @Javacisnotrecognized _^_
item.description:
@Javacisnotrecognized wrote:

JavaScript FTW@!@342

Perfect for resizing in an instant

<3 body onLoad

How well do you know JavaScript? Because it can change the parameters of anything if you use document.getElementById() first.

For example

<form id=stupidExample action=http://www.I.suck.at/makingforms>

to

document.getElementById('stupidExample').action="http://yay4JavaScript.com/";

Read full topic

item.title: Screen resolutions
item.dc:creator: @Kimber Kimber
item.description:
@Kimber wrote:

Hmm yeah, I usually just do it all by code. I find it easier than dreamweaver which I guess is why I always make incompatible sites.

Read full topic

item.title: Screen resolutions
item.dc:creator: @Skating_On_Java Elite2142
item.description:
@Skating_On_Java wrote:

Aftermath_96:

You could try using something like Dreamweaver to get it for everything, and I’d recommend a table layout because you can make sure everything goes in the right place.

^^ i would try that.

Read full topic

item.title: Screen resolutions
item.dc:creator: @kloplop321 kloplop321
item.description:
@kloplop321 wrote:

You can look for a javascript that will detect the resolution then redirect to a php page with the res. then echo the desired page according to the res.

Read full topic

item.title: Screen resolutions
item.dc:creator: @Aftermath_961 Aftermath
item.description:
@Aftermath_961 wrote:

You could try using something like Dreamweaver to get it for everything, and I’d recommend a table layout because you can make sure everything goes in the right place.

Read full topic

item.title: Screen resolutions
item.dc:creator: @Kimber Kimber
item.description:
@Kimber wrote:

Im aware of this, and I suck at compatibility. But thank you for making me remember that even if I find a way to make it compatible in IE6, it may still be wrong for another browser!

Read full topic

item.title: Screen resolutions
item.dc:creator: @Aftermath_961 Aftermath
item.description:
@Aftermath_961 wrote:

Make it compatible for all browsers and resolutions.

Don’t depend on the browser to format it correctly, because most browsers interpret HTML differently.
Use specific things like heights, widths, etc, and it’ll look good for everything.

Read full topic
